July 25, 1999: Fiction
HANNIBAL, by Thomas Harris. (Delacorte, $27.95.) Seven years after his escape,
the fiendish psychiatrist Hannibal Lecter is still at large.
GRANNY DAN, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A woman learns about her
grandmother's Russian past.
WHITE OLEANDER, by Janet Fitch. (Little, Brown, $24.) The ordeals of growing
up as experienced by a teen-age girl whose single mother murders a lover.
MOTHER OF PEARL, by Melinda Haynes. (Hyperion, $23.95.) The lives of a 28-
year-old black man and a 15-year-old white girl converge in Petal, Miss., in the
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $17.95.) A British boy finds trouble when he returns to a
witchcraft school.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school for
witchcraft.
A VERY STRANGE TRIP, by L. Ron Hubbard and Dave Wolverton. (Bridge, $25.)
An Army truck driver transports a contraband Russian time machine.
STAR WARS: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace, by Terry Brooks.
(Lucas/Ballantine, $25.) How it all began for Anakin Skywalker (a k a Darth
Vader).
LAKE NEWS, by Barbara Delinsky. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) To escape a
scandal in the big city, a talented singer flees to her seemingly idyllic hometown.
THE TESTAMENT, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A reclusive billionaire,
a burned-out lawyer and a missionary are brought together by a startling secret.
THE GIRL WHO LOVED TOM GORDON, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $16.95.) A
young girl who is a fan of the Boston Red Sox gets lost in the woods.
MCNALLY'S DILEMMA, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $24.95.) Archy McNally
investigates the death of a Florida playboy who lived a tangled life.
A NEW SONG, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $24.95.) A clergyman and his wife move
600 miles from home.
THE GIRLS' GUIDE TO HUNTING AND FISHING, by Melissa Bank. (Viking,
$23.95.) The progress of a young New York woman through the terrain of sex and
love.
Non-Fiction
SHADOW, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) How the Watergate
scandal affected the Administrations of Richard Nixon's five successors.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The
lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War
II.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author
recalls his old college mentor.
I AIN'T GOT TIME TO BLEED, by Jesse Ventura. (Villard, $19.95.) Reflections on
politics and other subjects.
THE FIRST WORLD WAR, by John Keegan. (Knopf, $35.) A historian recounts
the 1914-18 conflict from the viewpoint of the strategists and the men in the
trenches.
ENCORE PROVENCE, by Peter Mayle. (Knopf, $23.) Further experiences in the
south of France.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead,
$22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
BELLA TUSCANY, by Frances Mayes. (Broadway, $25.) An American writer
remembers a spring and summer spent in the romantic sections of Italy.
THE CENTURY, by Peter Jennings and Todd Brewster. (Doubleday, $60.) An
account of the 20th century.
YESTERDAY, I CRIED, by Iyanla Vanzant. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) A counselor
describes how she turned painful experiences into feelings of hope.
CINDERELLA STORY, by Bill Murray with George Peper. (Doubleday, $19.95.)
Golfing adventures.
EVERY MAN A TIGER, by Tom Clancy with Chuck Horner. (Putnam, $27.95.) The
novelist and a retired Air Force general examine the Persian Gulf war.
CONVERSATIONS WITH GOD: Book 1, by Neale Donald Walsch. (Putnam,
$19.95.) The author addresses questions of good and evil, guilt and sin.
ELEANOR ROOSEVELT, by Blanche Wiesen Cook. (Viking, $34.95.) The second
volume of a biography covers her initial years as the nation's First Lady.
DEADLINES AND DATELINES, by Dan Rather. (Morrow, $23.) Essays about the
events and personalities of the 1990's by the television news anchor.
